thread.title: Treasury makes further moves to sell off bank stakes in Lloyds and RBS
thread.title_full: Treasury makes further moves to sell off bank stakes in Lloyds and RBS

title: Treasury makes further moves to sell off bank stakes in Lloyds and RBS
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Fri, Oct 9, 2015, 09:12 BST - UK Markets close in 7 hrs 18 mins Treasury makes further moves to sell off bank stakes in Lloyds and RBS By Marion Dakers | Telegraph – 4 minutes 44 seconds ago 2.1863 0.0000 
Government holding in Lloyds falls below 11pc as the state converts its non-voting shares in RBS (LSE: RBS.L - news ) 
The Treasury’s drip-feed sale of shares in Lloyds Banking Group (Other OTC: LLOBF - news ) has taken the public stake in the bank below 11pc, ahead of a retail share offering next year. 
The Government now owns 10.97pc of the company, down from 11.98pc on September 25 and almost 25pc a year ago, according to stock market announcements. The most recent tranche of shares has been bought for approximately half a billion pounds. 
Investment bankers at Morgan Stanley (Xetra: 885836 - news ) have been selling the shares on behalf of UK Financial investments, the state agency responsible for managing the shareholdings in the bailed out banks for the Treasury. 
The sell-off to institutions will continue until the end of the year, before ordinary investors buy up to £2bn of discounted shares to conclude the bank’s seven-and-a-half years of Government support. 
"I am determined to build on this success by making Lloyds shares available to the public next spring, so that we can build a share-owning democracy and continue to reduce our national debt," said George Osborne, the Chancellor. 
Separately, the Treasury has given Royal Bank of Scotland notice that it wants to convert 51 billion 'B' shares that were issued during the bailout into 5.1 billion new ordinary shares, removing another hurdle to the bank’s move into full private ownership. 
The first batch of the state’s RBS shares was returned to private hands in August when the Treasury sold a 5.4pc holding to take its economic ownership down from 78.3pc to 72.9pc. 
The newly-announced conversion means that all of the Government’s holding will be through ordinary shares. 
The B Shares were given to the Treasury as part of the 2008 bailout, to ensure the bank did not breach rules on no investor owning more than 75pc of the firm.
